sentence: KathNiel's G
T movie
: I don't usually go watch local films, but KathNiel just have that thing that makes me not want to miss it every single time (I always watch on it's first day too

) lol

So here's my non-biased review
I will try to be as objective as possible
For someone who appreciate movies a whole lot, it is such a hard thing to please me and my siblings when it comes to movies
I was a bit hesitant before watching the movie, rom-com-drama movies are not really my type
This movie, went beyond my expectations
The cinematography wasn't as great compared to their Crazy Beautiful You movie, but nonetheless, it really went beyond expectations
I never expected it to be as creative and dynamic because of the simple setting and story line, but it was unbelievably quite on par with CBY
Kudos to the team for that
Story wise, it was that kind of movie which is really simple and not as complicated as others but it really brought out the feels
I specifically loved the beginning part the most
It's not common for Filipino movies to start that way but it did
Not gonna spoil the scenes though
Gonna leave it all to you to find out how beautifully catching it was
Another thing to note, was the transition to each and every scene, the voice overs and the story flow
It's meticulously put together that you'll be hooked the whole time you're watching the movie
The dynamics was there too, will sound cliche but it was a roller coaster of feelings
When you think you're through all the heavy scenes, and can feel the whole cinema audience sharing that light feeling, they'll hit you with the feels again
To the couple, Kathryn and Daniel, they were really the one who brought the movie to life
Unlike, Barcelona: A Love Untold, we saw how great of a supporting actor Joshua is and for me, he was one of the actors who brought the movie to life
In here, it was all them
Not discrediting other actors, they all did a good job
Darren is a revelation, the kid is a multi-talented person
We can't really say anything about Miss Jean Garcia cause she really is a legend
Other cast's acting were quite bland but it was still a good one
Joross and another actor's cameo was also on point
For those who never had a relationship like me, Juan Miguel Severo and Ria Atayde was the most relatable one
They really showed what friends do, it was real, really genuine
Back to KathNiel, I really feel like this is their best movie yet
Kathryn was on her zone, she really owned this one
She literally shone her, she really showed her vulnerability and it's super far from when she was starting and her teen movies
We really saw Kathryn, not Kathryn with Daniel but Kathryn
Kathryn herself
Daniel is a natural, we all know that
I can't even explain how great of an actor he is, whenever he accepts a character, you won't see a trace of the Daniel Padilla in real life but he really gets into the character and owns it
He was the best Primo just as Kathryn was the best George
They really owned this one
Direk Cathy showed us again why she is a blockbuster director
She is a legend
Maybe not indie wise, cause that's not her forte
But we can always trust Direk Cathy to bring out all the emotions, may it be tears of both joy and pain, all the laughs and all the frustrations
Rated it 8 because there will always be room for improvement for all the actors and the movie itself, but overall it is a really great one
A must-watch
TOUCHING AND UNIQUE: As a non-fan of the usual romantic Filipino films, especially those starring love teams, "The Hows of Us" is a unique film thanks to the set up
It's also nice to see a nice twist to the what's essentially the same formula

it won't surprise me if you two brag the Best / Promising Actress and Actor of the year

Not your typical Filipino Rom-com: A strong and raw depiction of a struggling relationship

A great movie where you can get life lessons: Kathryn Bernardoand George and Daniel Padilla as primo are schoolmates who fall in love
George preparing to get into medical school and Primo a musician waiting for his band to hit it big
Together, in a house they inherited from George's grand aunt, they dream of great success and promise to support each other no matter what
But what happens when the dream of success doesn't come for one of them
Primo doesn't get the big break he's been working for and turns into a difficult and arrogant artist who can't even help with the bills
Faithful George stays true to her promise to support Primo through it all
that is until she reaches her breaking point and gives up
Dejected, Primo walks out and does not look back
Years later, Primo comes back and changed man
And Geogre still pursuing her dream
Primo want to George back to his life but Goerge won't repeat or continue her life with Primo because she remember the days when she choose Primo than her dream and that ruin everything for her
But the days and months past George realize that she still love Primo because all of a sudden Primo tries to do everything for George but George did not see that effort
until George found the letter from Primo on the day that she decided to leave Primo
The letter make George realized that she still have love Primo
In the end they both back and leave together
The Hows Of Us is a moving story about the ups and downs of real-life relationships

Ano yon

There used to be a time when the powers-at-be were trying to convince people that Daniel Padilla was cool, casting him as the broody teenage bad-boy that had to be won over by the steely determination of his good-girl paramour Kathryn Bernardo
But he's not cool, at least in that way
He's got a big goofy smile, a friendly presence, and an earnestness that gives his characters surprising vulnerability
His growth as an actor largely involves him being comfortable up on screen, being some version of himself that's closer to who he really is
And this leads to the best bits of this movie, which almost seem to happen in a vacuum of narrative
It doesn't matter what came before or what might happen after
In the moment, it just looks like these two kids are enjoying themselves

Kathryn Bernardo hasn't quite kept up with Padilla's development, her performances getting a little stiffer as she gets older, but their clear affection for one another smooths out a lot of these scenes
But these moments don't actually exist in a vacuum
There's a movie around it, and like so many local big romcoms, there are just too many things going on

All the classic formula markers are there, too: some sort of medical problem, some parental issues and a whole bunch of characters that exist purely to tell the leads what they're supposed to be feeling
The movie stretches into two hours with the added weight of these rote elements, and by the time they fly off to some foreign land, it kind of feels like an entirely different movie
It shifts focus completely, and starts filling in even more backstory through yet another character that just says everything outright

The story they end up telling is actually pretty simple, but there are just so many other things that crowd out the much more affecting core of this story: two people still clearly in love with each other, just trying to overcome the hurt that also still exists between them
In bits, in moments, the two kind of make that work
But the movie itself feels so caught up in the norms of their genre to just let the leads take the lead
This film presents a distinct, powerfully affecting kind of love story to prove that the standard CGM formula has still some unique perspectives to spin and explore
Here’s a mind dump (with little spoilers) rendered in the same fashion as the film’s break-build narrative, starting off with negatives (baka awayin ako ng fans, lol), wrapping up with positives
The opening voiceovers are certainly moving but seem lengthier than necessary
I hate that I feel like I’m being spoon-fed
Daniel’s character is rather poorly developed
And the choice to reveal his backstory through another character’s verbose lines is quite a disappointment
I am totally confused about (what I think is) the turning point where Primo has to leave because that’s obviously what he is asked to, then is instantly being chased by George afterwards
There is no question about Kathryn’s acting, but seriously I’m like, “Girl, why are you crying
Pinaalis mo ‘di ba
” And when he returns, she says something like “That’s not what I actually meant because I was just tired, and that I wanted you to fight for us that night
” Ang labo
The prepossessing bike scene gets less delightful when Primo starts throwing gibberish pick-up lines
Ganda na sana eh
Rickety in part but there’s so much that makes it worthy as a whole:5
Editing does not look as though it’s rushed
‘Buti naman
A dialogue-heavy scene backdropped by Amsterdam’s glaring flower fields and lovely sunset is my favorite
How would you feel if you’re in a beautiful place, talking to someone you love about how your lives got better after you painfully parted ways
Tearful acceptance, ganun
Ako, hindi ko alam
Second favorite is the harana/apology scene
Pain and kilig stirred together
It may not be picture-perfect, but it’s a warehouse of authentic messages, inspirational ideologies, and lessons in love, which I gladly take away:- Relationships take great, great effort to maintain
It’s easy to give love and be happy when things are going well
But what happens when life suddenly feels as though it’s caving in with a spirit-crushing weight
Ang tanong eh kung kaya mo pa
Pero kung siya ayaw na, tama na
Ginawa ko na ‘yan
Okay naman ako
Pero ako lang ‘yun
- I give a nod everytime Primo says “Sayang iniwan kita, nagkahiwalay tayo,” and George will answer “but we became better persons
” Eh kasi tama naman
We don’t grow when things are easy, comfortable, and effortless
We grow when we face something beyond what we’re capable of handling
Kahit magkahiwalay pa kayo
Again, ako lang ‘to
- For the most beautiful part: Just because we think our heart is broken doesn’t mean it’s incapable to love again
(Sa’kin talaga galing to
) It’s those times when we have to step aside, heal in whatever foolish way we can, and remind ourselves of what keeps us going

It’s when we think na wala nang dahilan magmahal ulit kasi masasaktan ka lang ulit, that instead of curling up and hiding from the world, we gather our scattered bits of resolve to keep moving forward, whether with someone from the past, with someone new, or with yourself alone
Friend, life is worth every single moment
Be open to lessons from your hardships and misfortunes — they will build within you an unshakable passion, acceptance, understanding, and LOVE
THOU redefines my idea of living life, makes me want to fall in love again
Solid first act
Gets droopy in the middle but is held up by Kathryn Bernardo's impeccable acting
Ends on a really sweet, heartfelt note
I really dislike films where the movie itself tries to force you to root for a deeply problematic relationship, and excuse selfish behavior
Other than Daniel Padilla, the film doesn't work at a fundamental level
It's that bad to me

but it tried too hard

Though there are these cringeworthy Amsterdam scenes and romantic lines that could have been more effective if it was said in vernacular, the formidable leads were still able to hit the soft spot with their relentless charm and chemistry
This is one of Molina's best films although, that's not really saying much to be honest

It's elevated by the thoughtful and strong performances of its two leads but it's ultimately let down by a script that relies too much on cheesy lines that never really feel necessary and sometimes, some scenes are just a bit longer than they should have been
Overall, it's still really entertaining and Padilla and Bernardo prove once again why they are huge stars

Georgina (Bernardo) ingin pasangannya, Primo (Padilla) lebih terlihat berjuang, padahal mereka punya 'pertempuran' dan cara berjuang yang berbeda dari sejak pertama mereka bertemu
Relate banget filmnya
di saat pasangan harus saling mendukung, dari yang awalnya percaya dengan passion Primo, dan menerima segala kekurangannya dan bersabar
Georgina, merasa lelah sekian lama bekerja sambil kuliah, membayar tagihan, mengurusi rumah warisan neneknya, sementara Primo sibuk mengejar passionnya, yang awalnya membuat Georgina jatuh cinta
Hubungan keduanya sirna, saat Georgina merasa lelah dengan perjuangannya, mengeluh dan marah untuk pertama kalinya dan mengusir Primo
Ia berharap Primo bertahan mendengarkan keluhannya, bersabar menghadapi amarahnya dan lebih berjuang membantu lelahnya
Tetapi Primo malah pergi, membawa kekecewaan, rasa tidak dipercaya dan kegagalan
Keduanya berpisah dan baru bertemu kembali setelah 2 tahun
Primo kembali lagi, berusaha memperbaiki, tapi Georgina menganggapnya sudah terlambat
Semua sudah berakhir, tanpa mereka ketahui rahasia dan 'pertempuran hati' yang Primo pendam 2 tahun yang lalu

Forget about the Filipino-romance formula plots, but the execution made me forget how appealing this can be

The lines said can be repeated by other Filipino drama-rom coms (or context are pretty much the same), but I just remembered that the screenwriters are the same people who wrote One More Chance which made me realize why this film gave much emotion

The story is plain simple and it was going okay as it goes along, but I think the father/Amsterdam thing was unnecessary, however, I'm not hating the not-tulips-but-other-flowers-on-the-field scene when they both finally realized they've become better people with their separation
It was also nice to see the evolution of this love team's acting; they just get better and better as time goes by, giving more opportunities for them to go with mature roles — including this one

I don't know if I have nearly as many questions about how this couple happened than I do about the one in "She's Dating a Gangster"

This onscreen romance between Kathryn Benardo and Daniel Padilla can only be healthier than their last one under Cathy Garcia-Molina, but we're still talking about an aspiring musician and a medical student moving in together after she inherits her great aunt's hows-I mean house
I don't know how mature the film itself is with that wordplay in the title, so of course it's not too long before the med student gets tired of supporting the bum

Years later, "he just happens" to return declaring that he is a "changed man", but at least sticks around when he discovers that his ex-girlfriend blew up her medical career to whine about breaking up with her boyfriend

As if that's not unhealthy enough, after they ruined their first relationship with too much pressure, they have to start a new one by selling the house and finding the female lead's estranged father before her brother goes blind from diabetes

Along the way, they figuratively return to the debate club where they literally met to assess the "hows" that will save these lovers, even though the only one that counts is that they're played by Kathryn Benardo and Daniel Padilla
Filipino cinema's hottest power couple are sure to draw a crowd to what bickering they can manage, but the film still has to pander to them to oblivion

The masses might be a bit thrown off by the film's wildly convoluted nonlinear storytelling, and even then, it's mostly hard to keep up with the rapid-fire progression of the characters' arc settling into the house and adapting to their draggier reunion some years later

Something as overdramatic as a flashback structure mostly just shows how contrived this thing is, as a simplistic melodrama that forces conflict in the flashback storyline to spice up an initially "happy" home and facilitate its downfall, and blows the reunion arc on either randomly searching for an estranged father or a grown-ass doctor screaming about the "tragedy" of getting dumped

This film deals with some pretty sophisticated themes on how individuals are complexly shaped by their relationship, and although fairly likable character undergo a lot of change, it's all undone by those "I can't live with you" confrontations and "I can't live without you" declarations

It's never a particularly well-written romp, of course, the comedy being almost singularly embarrassingly juvenile screwball banter with friends or cutesy shenanigans with the couple, whose romantic interplays are devalued by sexual tension and saccharine dramatic progression

For the film to talk about moving into an adult relationship, this is in no way an adult movie, with Cathy Garcia-Molina being just one of many writers on a flimsy committee, and giving up on carrying this above that as directress
As full-hearted as her frantic overstylization, over-scoring, overpacing and overall overhandedness are, it's yet more grating pandering that wears down a superficial romantic dramedy
It's just a fluff piece, and it's sure to please the crowd, sometimes with actually tasteful elements

The wooded suburban house is a key character, and a comely one at that, with a beauty and humility beaming with some of the truest romance in the atmosphere of a film all about the hassle of a couple settling down
This sentimental tone is carried over by Jessie Lasaten's sweetly bright score and Noel Teehankee's dreamily polished cinematography, but without the maturity naturally inherent in that home
Cathy Garcia-Molina's direction just keeps going too far with the romantic disposition, but no matter how cloying this gets, there's always such honesty in such fiery emotion

As melodramatic as the film gets, there are times when Garcia-Molina is simply owning up to that with her dreamy sentiments, trusting that the cheese will be grounded by the admittedly fairly solid character factor

It's a romantic drama about growing up that is in no way grow-up, until there comes a point in both the flashback and present-day segments when the characters really start to break through, losing a grip of their prospects under the pressure of making a home, then reuniting some time later to further contemplate how they function as a unit

Juxtaposing these two processes deepen fairly sharp themes on understanding the differences between healthy dependency and toxic codependency; sacrificing your own prospects and supporting someone else's; and succumbing to the burden of a serious relationship and giving it time to breathe

I can tell you one thing: it's getting hard to see Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla functioning without each other, their radiant chemistry continuing to flourish alongside their bubbly charms and often surprisingly piercing emotional forces, as they try to hold together a film that is having a harder time managing fluff with true maturity

The nonlinear narrative is just part of the incessant contrivances that devalue a would-be mature love story, but not like the grating humor, histrionics and overstylization that render this strict pandering, with enough charm in its craft and punch-up, if not enough depth in its character developments and the leads' chemistry, to save Cathy Garcia-Molina's "The Hows of Us" a likably farcical romantic drama that warms your heart in some places and leave it cold in others
5/5 - Adequate

The Amsterdam sequence—you don't even go here Just when I thought this film strayed away from formulaic, comfortable rom-com that never fails to have: a hugot festival, kids with parental issues, and the need to go to special places to release repressed feelings, instead it stayed loyal to it

There's something about how voices are amplified too much or smoothened out
Sometimes, it looks like it was dubbed which I find disturbing
Anyway, Kathryn Bernado's acting is stale as ever and I almost pity Daniel Padilla who caged in roles as a charismatic loverboy that it scares me to see him outside it
While the start and main problem were promising, the formulaic resolution was very disappointing

I just don't get the point of already starting with the post-breakup, and then showing the redeeming value of Primo was with him all along, even before the breakup, as if pointing out that it was all a misunderstanding
This subtly puts the blame on George for not knowing that Primo was actually a good man (she should have just trusted him
This should have been a film about HOW Primo acknowledges his accountability and redeems himself, and HOW George finally finds in herself the courage to forgive and love again
That would have been less formulaic, less harmful, and most probably very endearing
Also, what's with the exaggerated acting
Almost all of them are good to great actors (except of course for Espanto), and yet most of them were also over the top
I think, because they have proven in their other projects that they can act, that it's a directorial problem
Which is also suprising, given that this is Garcia-Molina we are talking about

This is the first Kathniel project i ever truly liked — loved even
In typical Star Cinema fashion, the movie starts with a chaotic scene depicting hyperactive leads that, somehow, lose that hyperactivity through the rest of the film
In another typical Star Cinema fashion, insert the need to shoot in a foreign country
I have to be honest, though — those Amsterdam scenes could have also panned out effectively if shot in some remote province in the Philippines
But, yeah, I know Amsterdam doesn’t require permits for filming there, so I guess Star Cinema took the opportunity to film and have a European vacation at the same time
Typical Filipino showbusiness tactic
Splitting the house in two - seen that many times, mostly in comedies
It did the job for this movie, though
It worked as a story device that did not feel forced
Anyway, Kathryn and Daniel have both really matured in this movie
Especially Kathryn — in all her previous movies where she was supposed to play an adult, she didn’t quite do so well
I mean, acting-wise, she did
But in terms of looks, she always looked like some teenager and, sometimes, even a child
So I commend the styling team for doing a good job with her look for “The How’s of Us”
Her screen presence matured
As for Daniel, boy, has he grown into a man
I especially love him in this role
I love it when men are depicted as soft, vulnerable, and pitiful — in the context of a love story, of course
And this — I cried
I tried to hold back the tears, but I just couldn’t
This is the true hallmark of good storytelling — when you fight your emotion, but it gets the better of you

"George, I'm sorry
""And what makes that sorry different from all your other sorrys before
"I've always been a devoted admirer of Kathniel, eagerly anticipating each of their upcoming movies
They stand out as my preferred Filipino loveteam, especially since I used to follow Social Seryes on Twitter inspired by their story
My admiration for Daniel Padilla and Kathryn Bernardo deepened after watching this particular film in theaters
While the movie's plot follows the typical, cliché, and foreseeable pattern of Filipino romance films, I found it delightful because of the remarkable chemistry between the two leads
Somehow, they infused it with a special and heartfelt quality
Kathryn Bernardo's acting deserves special recognition; her exceptional performance left a lasting impact, even stirring my emotions at 3:00 AM
Forgiveness, a challenging virtue, becomes particularly daunting when faced with someone who has caused you pain and shattered your self-esteem
The decision to forgive or harbor perpetual resentment carries immense pressure, complicated further by the fear of disappointing those opposed to your chosen path
I won't deny that Primo was quite the jerk in the past, blinded by his dreams to the harsh realities around him
Despite acknowledging George's struggles in a letter, he failed to take meaningful action
His reckless behavior, fueled by alcohol, exacerbated their financial woes
Fortunately, George displayed remarkable understanding and selflessness
It's heartening that Primo eventually transformed into a better person, learning from his mistakes and genuinely committed to fixing everything
In contrast, I resonate more with George's approach
I refuse to let the same person inflict harm on me once again

At two hours long, "The Hows of Us" was limited severely by so much bloat and so many tropes that it really made us wonder why they just didn't tell a straightforward story in the first place
But don't get us wrong though, it wasn't a bad experience at all and we actually found ourselves liking this film much more than we anticipated
But its barely middling middle section should have been reworked maybe even removed
For years, Jo (Kathryn Bernardo) and Primo (Daniel Padilla) had a long-lasting relationship so much so that when Jo’s Aunt died, she left her house to the both of them
But with Primo, a budding musician, failing to attain the success that he feels he is beholden to and with Jo feeling that Primo’s failures are holding her back, Primo abandons Jo all by herself
A few years pass by when Primo suddenly shows up and wants to fix the wrongs he has done in the past - including his relationship with Jo
But this isn’t as simple as it sounds as Jo plans to sell their house soon and hasn’t really forgiven and forgotten that Primo left her to fend for herself
We must admit that “The Hows of Us” left us with a heavy dose of mixed feelings
On one hand, its narrative and story really had potential to be substantially and emotionally moving
But the film also suffers because it felt it needed to do genre tropes within its story that was just unnecessary
For example, there’s a parent or sibling who suffers a sickness in the most opportune time or simply travelling to a foreign country
We wished it just told a more straightforward and down-to-earth story - one that we could actually imagine happening in real-life and not one obviously written for the big screen
While the overall narrative was bloated, the film actually had bright spots
In fact, the first thirty minutes and last thirty minutes were outstanding in our opinion
It had us gripping our seats with emotionally moving moments
Of course, these scenes were bolstered by the great chemistry and acting between Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla
Overall though, “The Hows of Us” will make you swoon in key moments and if that’s what you’re after, you’ll actually find it a story worth experiencing

this is peak Pinoy romcom cinema
it has everything you’d expect; flashbacks and flashforwards, a junket trip to Europe, 2 charismatic leads, etc
what separates this from the fluff is its execution, the story (up until the end) is well crafted and avoids the natural pitfalls of the premise it set up for itself
the protagonists have agency and do not make any decision just for plot contrivance
not to say this is a perfect movie, it has its problems— the editing and pacing is not quite there

it spends way too much time meandering through Amsterdam, and crafting a Pixar Up-like sequence in the beginning was not necessary if they were only going to spend a lot of running time going through the past all over again, so there is no economy of storytelling present
my biggest problem though is the ending
i understand why they did it the way they did, but imo it was completely unnecessary and actually harms the characters’ growth during the movie

SPOILER what the ending does is retcon the movie’s story; we find out in the end that Primo actually knew he was being a selfish prick before he left, but instead of actually doing something about it, he instead, what, wrote a letter
that makes it okay
that actually makes it worse, because now we know he had a CHOICE to be better 2 years ago, but he chose not to
his 2 years of change therefore did not matter because it implies he in fact didn’t change, at all
then they have George APOLOGIZING to him
as if anything was her fault
that is wrong on so many levels
this development looks unfortunately to have been put there only to create a reason for George to get back together with Primo in time for the movie to end, but this was completely unnecessary
Primo has grown as a person, he’s already shown this to George, and George already acknowledges that he has
there was no need for the letter

instead, what they should have done was, after all the items have been sold off, have both of them say farewell to their past selves, the people that owned that house, and reintroduce each other as new people
have the movie end with George agreeing to go on a first date with Primo, a chance that this time around, things will work out

The Hows of Us is a drama romcom type film about a Filipino boyfriend musician and a girlfriend on her way to being a doctor growing individually as well as through their relationship in ties with their new home purchase

The film touches on aspects of romance/love, aspects of grief loss, aspects of depression, aspects of addiction, aspects of being a homeowner, aspects of negative pride, aspects of romantic relationships/friendships, aspects of maturity, aspects of family, and aspects of diabetic retinopathy amongst other points
The camera work is on point
The acting partners fulfill the film
I find the film funnier than sad
The film has some interesting messages about relationships
Though I think a lot is simply put together to fluff the film/make it make more sense toward the end, I find the film entertaining

The film's premise surely captures the kind of sentimentality that is born out of selfless devotion
George (Kathryn Bernardo) represents every doting lover who understands that love is both a struggle and sacrifice
But she's human enough to reach her breaking point, that non-singular moment Primo (Daniel Padilla), her lover, erodes into a miserable man
That's outright promising, given an opportunity to go deep into the characters' core
Until the narrative submits to Star Cinema formula

While Primo tries to win George back, a lot of other things happen, all brazenly pointing to them realizing they need to be back together, even if he decides to set her free--a banal device that aims to make love look elusive but more intense
Because how are these two characters supposed to respond to other charcters whose sole duty is to remind them that they still love each other
The sequences in Amsterdam feel like you're watching a different film, with characters so eager to accomplish something for a great cause
The attempt at proving its significance by way of editorializing the flowers and the sunset does not put weight on either the characters or the narrative itself
Daniel effortlessly delivers, his eyes expressing the right emotions
Kathryn tries hard, a few times she's hitting it
Other times she's like a dainty, vulnerable young girl being forced to battle tough times
Her eyes convey ambiguity rather than perceptive and penetrating responses that don't demand words
Her delivery of "quotable quotes" and the lines in the debate scene sounds like a graded recitation (yung mukhang minemorize nang maigi)

And then the film gets too didactic, telling us what we should make of how Primo and George triumphed at their story and how we should distinguish battle and war as metaphors for love (kung maka-figure of speech
The film is supposed to tackle maturity in relationship, but it appears that its depiction does not quite go with its marketing
And Star Cinema is not bothered by such incongruency
It just continues to shape love through a narrative that always turns factitious and simplistic
It does not mind reducing it into the fundamentals of melodrama and simplified association or discourse

The Hows of Us is in fact an anti-love story
The movie explores not the best moments in a relationship but sets it’s focus on the moments that were the beginning of the end

Bernardo and Padilla act so damn good in this film that I had to check if they indeed broke up in real life
So many emotional moments and the question “Who’s right
” pull the viewer into the story
The rain scene is one of the most legendary moments in Filipino cinema for me
So many emotions with so less words really got me
I really loved the movie and can understand why every Filipino I met recommended me this masterpiece
It’s worth watching

Perhaps the most formally assured of these--Garcia-Molina plays with temporality in interesting ways, and utilizes spaces extremely well, using set design to suggest barriers between her leads--and these are my favorite KathNiel performances so far, but, I found the story a bit too busy, cramming extra sub-plots (a health scare AND a long-lost father

) that distract from the central relationship (and they do much more than merely distract: they actively conspire against it, as it keeps alive the dream that external events could solve the problems in their relationships
which is never the case, the changes must come from within

)But perhaps I'm being harsh, as this is a serious, adult drama (albeit with moments of levity), one that isn't content with the rosy-eyed "relationships are easy" view (nor one that ignores its characters material circumstances; money pressures drive all the key events in the film)

The Hows of Us (2018) bercerita tentang sepasang kekasih yang pernah saling mencintai, kemudian putus dan bersatu kembali
Terdengar simpel, sederhana dan sudah ketebak
Tapi yang membuat film ini berbeda dengan drama percintaan pada umumnya adalah pengemasannya
Pemilihan kata dalam dialognya yang sempurna, banyak yang relate dengan kisah seperti ini dan film ini juga sangat jujur dan realistis
Cathy Garcia-Molina berhasil mengangkat kisah biasa yang sering dialami dalam hubungan, sesuai realita, namun dikemas dengan sangat baik
Film kedua dari sutradara perempuan Filipina Cathy Garcia-Molina yang aku tonton

Berawal dari Hello, Love, Goodbye (2019) dengan soundtracknya "Ikaw At Ako" yang masih terngiang-ngiang dikepala menuntunku ke film ini, dan aku ketagihan dengan caranya bertutur dalam filmnya, jujur aku menikmatinya
The Hows of Us (2018) juga kabarnya memecahkan banyak rekor perfilman di Filipina dan menjadi film terlaris sepanjang masa di Filipina
Duet Kathryn Bernardo dan Daniel Padilla udah kayak benar-benar pasangan pada umumya, natural kali gak lebay dan berlebihan
Oh ya baru tau juga aku kalo mereka katanya dinobatkan sebagai pasangan klop yang sering dipasangkan diberbagai serial drama dan film
Kalo di Indo mungkin kayak Rizky Nazar sama Michelle Ziudhit kali ya, yang selalu jadi pasangan di FTV, film, atau series
Makanya chemistri mereka berdua udah matang kali

Streaming on Netflix now is this topgrossing 2018 Filipino drama that i somehow liked and shamefully but not secretly enjoyed and bawled my eyes out to
It tells the story of former lovers Primo and George who, at the beginning of the film, relive the days and sad occasions that led to their break-up
For fans of Filipino tearjerkers, a box of tissue may not be enough for this film
It will squeeze you out dry but you will not be complaining
This movie hits all the right formula in the genre
From the beautiful cast to the relatable relationship drama that’s been a staple of Philippine cinema for decades now
The story is somewhat typical but the storytelling is fresh
The conflict is as old as Sharon Cuneta’s first movie (or could be older) but the execution somehow feels novel
There are many cutesy scenes definitely constructed for the diehard fans of the loveteam but it somehow does not offend or get in the way of the developing drama
There is a subplot that will not ordinarily work but somehow works here
Every emotion this movie elicits from the audience is definitely earned
The great character actress Odette Khan appears in a cameo towards the end of the movie that only made me love this film more

”This is the moral of the movie
George and Primo showed a realistic relationship
It is not always a romantic one, sometimes it can be sad and heartbreaking
They let each other because they are tired — but letting go each other makes them grow and be the person they want to be
It is a matter of staying through thick and thin, through your darkest days
It is all about the patience we have in love
Sometimes we get tired, but it doesn't mean we don't want anymore
We just get tired, but we can rest
Maybe one of the lines that I can forget is, “we cannot survive to a battle if we fight each other, but staying together can conquer the battle
”This is one of the best Filipino movie I've ever watch, and undeniably the best KathNiel film ever produced

unmasking the romanticized toxic relationship in this film A movie that challenges to explore the sinister aspects of romance exists in an era where love stories predominantly captivate us as individuals
The movie "The Hows Of Us" defies preconceived assumptions of what romance is and instead leads us on an introspective excursion through the perilous waters of toxic relationships
This movie analysis challenges our preconceived ideas and compels us to face the unsettling reality that love can at times be…

I think we can see parts of ourselves on both George and Primo
May mga panahon na we are ready to give everything up for our partners, even our individual dreams, hoping that everything will work out in the end
After all, sino bang hindi gusto yung taong mahal nila hanggang sa dulo, sa dulo kung saan masaya na kayo
Minsan din tayong naging Primo; desperately chasing our passions in life kahit hindi pa praktikal
Well, art should be a liveable job naman technically, but we all know the reality rn
Still, we all had a little bit of Primo in ourselves believing na what if our passion can be our career at the same time
But mahirap din maging George at Primo
While Primo was chasing his dreams, he forgot that he has a partner to take care of and consider
Si George naman, kakaasikaso at asiste kay Primo, nakalimutan na yung mga sarili niyang pangarap
For me, this is what made the movie realistic
What I didn't like though was the fact na nagkabalikan sila and how they approached it
Para kasing nabura rin kung gaano ka-shitty yung ginawa ni Primo kay George over the course of their relationship
For me, dapat hindi sila nagbalikan talaga
Hence 4 stars

+ There is a hint of a better-written film in "The Hows of Us"
The supposed premise of lovers continuing their emotionally halted journey in life together starts of strong
But with the number of expositions squattered throughout this film, mediocre characterizations, and underbaked romance, this film fails in deliverying a more memorable love-story
Its themes of redemption, growth, and forgiveness seems to be lop-sided in parts, and Kathryn Bernardo's George was poorly written—though Kathryn gave an ecstatic performance
Daniel Padilla as Primo, on the other hand, also gave enough nuance to make his character charming, and surprisingly earnest
Though much is to be desired in how this movie had told us its story, still, there is enough charm in here to win you over, even if it doesn't give you a lasting impression

revisiting this movie, whether it’s watching the whole thing or just watching clips of it, always makes me cry very very ugly tears especially the scene where george finally gets to read the letter primo wrote for her 2 years later  this movie just portrays the heartbreak of meeting the right person at the right time yet circumstances and bad choices getting in the way so beautifully, it just hits you right to the corei’ve never personally experienced anything george and primo have, at least not to that degree, but they made me feel like i carried george’s burden and felt the guilt primo felt the entire time  these characters are just work of fiction yet they feel SO real, i honestly think they’re the most “human” characters ms

cathy g molina has created yet other than popoy and basha, which is already an impressive feat considering how one more chance and ESPECIALLY a second chance depicted the feeling of inadequacy in both marriage and your career

knowing that your s/o could do SO much better than you and it’s just agonizing to watch popoy slowly antagonize the woman he loves as he gets consumed by his own insecurities while basha’s doing her best to fix the damage that’s been donebut anyways to anyone who hasn’t watched the hows of us AND a second chance, 10/10 movies, both tear-jerkers, filipinos are the masters of romance-dramas idc if i’m biased, yes this review is just me singing praises for the director’s writing but

Strictly speaking, probably the best of the Kathniel movies
The one where both put in their most rounded performances, both charming and weighty when necessary
Beyond that, they're supported by much better material than in any of their other films

So much feels authentic and even the silliness of the core concept (dividing a house in half out of spite) feels grounded in a strong emotional reality that it passes by without much resistance from myself
There's also just a lot of interesting visual ideas going on here
Not all of them land perfectly, but I find myself appreciating all of them
In all her best work, Cathy Garcia-Molina has this very strong eye for divisions and framing and how that relates to the characters on screen
Obviously the divided house concept gives her a lot of chance to play with these ideas and generally speaking, they work to the film's benefit more than they detract
Where the film suffers is where it has to bow to the studio tentpole formula
Lengthy travel sequences get included in films like this as a means for the intended audience to live vicariously through the characters
Can't afford to go to The Netherlands
You can at least watch your favorite romcom team go instead
The Netherlands is a beautiful country but the entire subplot around Kathryn's brother and long lost father is just bloat that detracts from the heart of the movie
If this film had simply been contented being a romantic comedy (leaning towards drama), it might have been great
The addition of the family drama weighs it down dreadfully
That being said, it's a good movie
Too much of it works and those first two acts are some of the best I've seen from Filipino mainstream studio films
The crown jewel of the Kathniel canon, yet to be topped

darren and his subplot ruined itfirst half of the film >>> because the second half (the amsterdam arc, specifically) seemed like a different movie

if the amsterdam arc focused more on primo's side (as the film was told from george's point-of-view), rather than the search for george and yohan's father (darren's subplot), the film would be much better and the ending could be ‘more justified

seeing the tulips was primo's and george's dream together
but things didn't go as planned

same as with life, you don't always get what you wished for but life will always find a way to give you something better or in their case, they became better persons despite the fact that they were unable to reach their dreams together as they had planned
speaking of the flower field scene, i truly wish they had given primo's side equal attention
i believe many viewers failed to notice his depression and suicidal phase
of course, it won't excuse him for what he did, but at least it shows that he didn't do it just because he wants to
overall, thou has lots of iconic lines that became part of philippine pop culture
also one of kathniel's best acting performances—daniel's quiet moments (internal) and kathryn's intense dialogues (external)
if not for darren's irrelevant subplot, this will dethrone ‘she's dating the gangster’ as my favorite kathniel film

Rewatching "The How's of Us," a film I once thought was close to perfect, I realize that my initial enjoyment for this film might have been misplaced
I used to think that this film was one of the more polished and masterfully written script, but my recent viewing revealed shortcomings that I just couldn't overlook
Beyond the cheesy dialogue, I found that many of the story points did not entirely make sense
The narrative, at times, felt forced, just to check off the boxes of what makes a tear-jerking romance drama film
This rewatch honestly left me disappointed, as I had expected more from a film I once held in high regard

Since the breakup of power couple Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla, it seems like the best thing to do is to have a bittersweet marathon of all their films together
Although the teen romance genre is not typically not my cup of tea, the wife and I was able to watch at least one Kathniel film - which turned out to be their last - The Hows of Us (2018)

Directed by the go-to filmmaker when it comes to romantic drama blockbusters, Cathy Garcia-Molina crafted something truly special that would resonate more to the love team's followers five years later
The film revolves around the central characters, George (Kathryn Bernardo) and Primo (Daniel Padilla), a couple whose relationship undergoes a tumultuous journey
The narrative ingeniously navigates through the highs and lows of their love story, exploring themes of commitment, dreams, and the inevitable challenges that life throws at them
The storytelling is compelling, keeping the audience engaged with a mix of heartwarming moments and gut-wrenching conflicts

By letting Bernardo and Padilla portray layered and maturing characters, this project breaks the conventional boundaries of the love team which became widely popular through their numerous rom-com TV serials
The commitment of the two young actors make this work as the story revolves around their truly relatable character arcs
Although the supporting cast could also use deeper exploration, the couple's natural chemistry is the beating heart of this film
It may have leaned more towards traditional romantic comedy/drama elements, but the film's success lies in its passionate execution, especially in terms of narrative exploration and character depth
The actors' real-life love story may have ended, but this film shall remain as a highlight of PH cinema

Man, this Filipino movie was the boss for a whole year, raking in the moolah like crazy
And you know what
Totally deserved it
Firstly, Kathryn Bernardo ditched the teen idol tag and went full-blown actress – nailed it
There's this scene that screams dramatic superstar
Secondly, it's got this crazy formula that somehow clicks
Imagine all genres crashing like a traffic jam, but hey, it works like magic
Drama, comedy, romance – it's a whole package
Thirdly, it's like a crash course in Filipino values – family vibes, chasing dreams, and growing old with your ride-or-die
Can't get more Filipino than this
And let's not forget the killer screenplay and the jaw-dropping scenes of Amsterdam
Pure awesomeness

*incoming word vomit, i will not reread this to check it the things i say make sense fjsdhfd*I watched this with a loud as-it-happens commentary on the decisions the characters make and I find myself acting like how people usually would advice their friends when they're with a /useless/ partner
I'd say "LEAVE HIM
" or "He isn't worth it
" or "There are other fish in the sea
Better fish
"But I found myself silently relating a bit too much to Primo as I watched
I know how comforting it is that you know that there's someone rooting for you in what you feel are your darkest times
The only difference is that I live alone, therefore there was no one to see me when my 'functional' mask is off
In a way, it's good to not reveal that to anyone
But at the same, it may have been helpful to have someone like Jo around
(anyway, therapy helps
you dont need a jowa to save you from yourself HAHA)My favorite part was when Jo opened up about how she felt about their breakup

The choice the scriptwriters made to have Jo angry at the fact that Primo left, rather than the fact that we was a piece of shit on the days leading to their breakup made it clear that she really was rooting for him
That her love for Primo was rooted in something deeper than the idea of what he could offer her
She was simply disappointed that he gave up on what they had when she started to break down as well
I definitely feel like their breakup was necessary
At that point, Jo's hope was the singular thread keeping that relationship intact, and hope can only take so much
So when it wasn't strong, the relationship had to unravel
And it was good that they both grew despite being apart
Did she have to go back to Primo
I don't know
If she didn't, i think it'll go to a "Past Lives" type of scenario when they meet each other again in the far far future, except with more contempt
On the subject of passion vs
I wish I knew the answer
I always always want people to choose passion
But I can't relate because I don't have passion
I simply have a drive to survive
So I go for practicality
But if I had passion like Primo, I understand why he acted the way he did
I always imagine that it must be nice to want something so strongly
Overall, I liked this movie

The Hows of UsOne of the best KathNiel films for me
It’s one of my feel-good Pinoy movies
I’ve seen it three times, and I just had some realizations about relationships
After rewatching it, I found myself reflecting again on how love can be so complicated
What makes it more meaningful is not just the love itself—but the presence of understanding, respect, and the choice to keep showing up for each other
It’s not always about grand gestures
Sometimes, it’s the quiet assurance, the willingness to stay, and the help you give one another when things get tough that matter the most
Love is not always filled with happy or funny days—there will be real struggles to face
But having a partner who truly gets you, who won’t make you feel like a burden even in your lowest moments—that’s something else
It’s a different kind of feeling when you’re sharing your life with someone who sees your mess and still chooses to stay
That kind of love feels safe
It feels like home
Living together isn’t easy
But what makes it bearable—even beautiful—is when both people make the choice to stay, to fight for the love they share
It should never be one-sided
A relationship thrives when both partners are making an effort
Communication, respect, loyalty, and understanding—these are the pillars that hold love together
Sharing a home means sharing lives, dreams, flaws, and even pain
It’s not just about romance; it’s about commitment
It’s choosing each other every day, even in the midst of exhaustion, misunderstandings, and storms
There will be moments of doubt, words spoken in anger, and days when love feels more like a burden than a comfort—but staying, especially during the storm, is what love truly asks of us
Before entering a lifelong commitment, ask yourself:Are you truly ready to live with someone through the calm and the chaos, the ease and the effort
Are you ready to love, not just in the good times—but especially in the hardest ones
Are you ready to choose them again and again, even when it’s no longer easy
The Hows of Us doesn’t just show us what love looks like—it shows us what it takes
And if you’re with the right person, every hardship turns into something beautiful

The How’s of Us captures the kind of relationship that feels real — messy, painful, and full of the quiet moments that make love worth holding onto
Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla deliver their best performances yet; their chemistry is raw and mature, showing what it really means to love someone through the highs and lows
It’s not just a romance — it’s a reflection on growing up, on chasing dreams without losing yourself (or the person you love along the way)
The emotions are so grounded that you can’t help but see a bit of yourself in Primo and George
Some scenes hurt to watch, but in the best way possible
The How’s of Us reminds us that sometimes love isn’t about staying the same — it’s about growing together, even when it hurts

Point for it being iconic
For the couples drowning in love and survival
Primo (Daniel Padilla) and George (Kathryn Bernardo) are the embodiment of “mahal pero pagod na
” Love alone isn’t enough when dreams and pride collide
The line that cut deepest: “Sawang-sawa na kong magmahal sa ’yo
” It’s cruel, yet so honest
This movie is about the wear and tear of long-term love—the kind that tests your patience and your will to stay
Pero the most painful line for me was George saying:“I needed you to fight for us that night, because I was tired fighting alone
”Ang bigat
Kasi love is supposed to be shared—hindi pwedeng isa lang ang lumalaban
When she said that, it showed how empty and one-sided their relationship had become

It’s the first time I’m writing a review for a romance movie, although I do actually watch some
This one hits different when it comes to love
The way they portrayed the characters, it’s just bitter yet sweet
My favorite scene is when they were outside during the rain—Joy’s dialogue is what you’d feel the most
She was giving her pieces one by one to her love, so she was left with nothing in the end
Despite that, Primo actually received nothing, because people do not get the ability to receive that
Only to suck it up
Both of them were drained and sad and lost
For Primo’s side, he was really a good man
Although for the scenes that he was facing bad things, he didn’t deserve Joy nor anything from her
I pitied him
But it doesn’t mean that Joy should feel that, too
That’s why when they got away from each other, it was probably to find themselves
That’s how I liked The Hows of Us
The ending is up to you, actually
Whether they ended up together or just friends
The only thing I hope is for them to be happy

The Hows of Us isn’t just a love story — it’s a crash course in growing up together and growing apart
Kathryn and Daniel turn Primo and George into that couple you root for even when they’re exhausting you, because the love feels real, messy, and lived-in
It’s the kind of heartbreak that stings extra, because it reminds you of the fights you’ve had, the dreams you’ve shelved, and the person you once promised forever to
The Hows of Us: loving you is easy, living with you is the plot twist

It made me realize na love isn’t always all flowers and kilig
It’s not just about the good stuff
You also love their moods, their flaws, the ugly sides
You love the whole person, hindi lang ‘yong version nila when everything’s okay
But at the same time, love isn’t always enough
Especially when you’re starting to lose yourself in the process
Like, what’s the point if you’re always putting them first, tapos ikaw, you forget your own needs, your goals, your peace just to keep them
That’s not love
That’s self-abandonment
And sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is to choose you

“as years passed, everything that made me fall in love with him, turned out to be the same things I hated about him
”it’s scary how we can be ugly to someone who used to see stars in our eyes
This one hurt differently— not in the loud, heart-wrenching way some love stories do, but in that slow ache of staying too long
Of loving past the expiration date
Of fighting for something that no longer knows how to fight back
George and Primo weren’t star-crossed or tragic in the classic sense
They were real
Still soft for each other beneath the bruises of all those unfinished conversations
And maybe that’s what made it worse— their love didn’t end with anger
It ended with the weight of trying
Again and again
And again
I didn’t cry at the big scenes
I cried when she stared at him from across the room and didn’t know what to say
I cried at the way he said “pangarap” like it used to mean us, and now it only means me
The film didn’t scream
It simmered
It dragged me through the quiet cruelties of outgrowing someone you still care for
It reminded me of the version of myself I stayed with too long
The promises we tried to keep when our hearts had already started packing
And yet— somehow— it wasn’t hopeless
It was sad, but not bitter
That’s harder to write
That’s harder to feel
It whispered,“You loved
You outgrew
You survived
”And sometimes, that’s the most devastating line of all
This film felt like a letter you never sent
The kind that sits in your notes app
Half bitter
Half soft
Fully human
If you’ve ever loved someone deeply and had to choose yourself anyway— this one will sting

it never meant he loved george less, he was just passion-driven, and that is never wrong
ang mali lang niya ay nagkulang siya para ipakita yon kay georgeeither way — love will either blind or wake us from reality
we do things out of spite for love even in the least expected times that we will
ibubuhos ang buong kaluluwa at pagkatao para sa taong mahal natin — but too much of something never ends well
“in order to win a war, you have to stay together
”that line hit hard because love isn’t about avoiding conflict, it’s about choosing to stay even when it’s hard
the hows of us reminded me that real love isn’t always romantic or dreamy
it’s work, patience, and showing up even when it hurts
what stood out to me was kung gano kadali sumuko when things get painful, and how rare it is to hold on
but sometimes, like the film said, all we need is a little patience
some relationships need space to grow
others grow best together
and figuring that out is part of the journey
i learned that love means constantly choosing each other
not just when it’s easy, but especially when it’s not
facing the problem together, talking, being tired together, resting when needed
that’s what makes love last
i hope one day i find a kind of love that feels safe, honest, and patient
and i hope that kind of love finds me, too

The House of Us is a quiet kind of heartbreak
It tells the story of two people who once shared the same dreams but slowly drifted apart
It is not the loud kind of love
It is the kind that stays even when things get hard
The kind that gets tired but never fully disappears
It shows how love can be full of promises, but life can still find a way to test every one of them
They love each other deeply, but they are no longer the same people who started the journey
And that is what hurts the most
Watching two people hold on while slowly breaking inside
The film reminds you of the love you once believed would last forever
The kind that felt like home
And when that love starts to fall apart, it does not shatter all at once
It fades
And yet, in all the breaking, there is still hope
Hope that love, when chosen again, can still heal
Even if nothing is the same anymore

The Hows of Us felt to me like a simple, yet not shallow romantic melodrama
It sits somewhere between emotional depth and surface-level storytelling, focusing on a couple navigating love, breakup, and reconciliation
The screenplay was simple but had an almost episodic feel to it, i wasn't annoyed by it though and actually enjoyed some of the sequences as well
The humor was a mix of slightly cringeworthy moments and genuinely funny ones

The romance, both in its joyful and sorrowful moments had a mixture of both melodramatic, over the top yet funny moments, dialogues that felt like lied between borderline cringe and genuinely touching and effectively playful at times as well The chemistry between the leads stood out

I liked them as a couple, and both gave good performances, the lady, maybe, more than the male lead, since the writers did give her a bit more importance with backstory, depth and dialogues and so the actress had more to work with in here
The Amsterdam scene was the only one that felt a little unnecessary

Even though it added depth to both characters, especially George and featured the important flower field moments, and the detailing regarding her wish to watch tulips and all, there was still something about it that felt out of place
And yeah, i guess, it was the location change that might've made me think that way

This movie isn't just a "movie" it's an emotional rollercoaster

The film portrays the struggles of a long-term relationship facing an unexpected Crisis, moment of heartbreak,the unspoken tension, and the agonizing process of trying to rebuild the trust this movie makes you feel everything is real
It shows that being in a relationship is not all about "love", "spark", and "kilig" There are times that you'll have a fight and you'll just throw hurtful words at each other
Not all the time it's all about love, but it's all about sacrifices and devotion
You'll sacrifice everything for your loved ones, until you get drained,tired, and until you don't have anything to yourself anymore because you give them all
"The Hows of us" hit me hard when the raining scene started
I found myself completely absorbed in the character's struggles

my guilty pleasure
Watching this was an experience that truly stayed with me  I remember settling in for the film, not knowing that it would stir up so many emotions and memories of my own ups and downs in love
From the very first scene, the realistic portrayal of a relationship’s joys and struggles pulled me into a world that felt both familiar and profoundly moving
What struck me most was the film’s honest depiction of the challenges that come with deep, enduring love
The story isn’t about a perfect romance; it’s about real-life conflicts, sacrifices, and the bittersweet moments that define our relationships
I found myself recalling personal experiences times when love meant both elation and heartache and this connection made the film’s narrative all the more powerful
The chemistry between KathNiel was undeniable  Their performances felt genuine, conveying the vulnerability and intensity of their characters’ journey
I was particularly touched by how their expressions and subtle gestures spoke volumes, often more than the dialogue could

It’s rare for a film to make you feel as if you’re living the characters’ experiences alongside them, and that’s something I felt deeply throughout the movie (I just want to mention this so bad ) Beyond the romance and drama, this prompted me to reflect on my own relationships
There were moments of quiet introspection scenes where the characters faced their inner battles and external pressures that resonated with me personally
The film’s pacing allowed for these moments to sink in, making the experience both cathartic and thought provoking
The cinematography was evident in every frame  The visual storytelling, from intimate close ups to sweeping shots of the setting, created an immersive atmosphere
I appreciated how the film balanced its dramatic highs with more tender, reflective scenes, offering a nuanced look at what it means to love and to let go
In the end I just want to say, AY LAB IT SO MUCH
The Hows of Us isn’t just a love story it’s a reminder of the complexities and realities of life
It left me with a sense of nostalgia and a deeper appreciation for the unpredictable nature of relationships
(which I don’t feel much anymore ‘cuz I just expect the worse) For anyone who has ever loved, lost, or simply wondered about the true nature of connection, THIS FILM IS DEF A MUST WATCH

The film beautifully captures the reality that love alone isn’t always enough
It’s messy, heartbreaking, and deeply relatable, showing the sacrifices and tough choices that come with commitment
With honest storytelling, stunning visuals, and raw emotions, The Hows of Us is an unforgettable film that lingers in your heart long after it ends

Reflection on The House of Us (2018)The 2018 Filipino film The House of Us, is an emotionally stirring drama that explores love, dreams, and the struggle to hold onto relationships despite life’s hardships
The movie follows the story of Primo (Daniel Padilla) and George (Kathryn Bernardo), a couple whose relationship is tested by ambition, miscommunication, and the harsh realities of life
Watching this film was a deeply emotional experience, as it delved into themes that felt incredibly real and relatable
It made me reflect on the complexities of love and the sacrifices that people make to sustain their relationships
One of the most striking aspects of The House of Us is how it captures the essence of Filipino relationships and family dynamics
The plot feels deeply Filipino because of its emphasis on love as not just an emotion but also a responsibility
Many Filipinos will see themselves in George and Primo characters who represent different perspectives on dreams and commitment
The film also highlights the idea of bahay, or home, as not just a physical structure but a place built through shared experiences and struggles
This theme resonates strongly with Filipino audiences, as family and home play a crucial role in Filipino culture
The sacrifices made by George and her struggle to balance love with self-respect mirror the reality of many Filipinos who navigate relationships while trying to improve their circumstances
The film also appears to reference other works in the romance and drama genre, particularly in how it presents its narrative and themes
For instance, it shares similarities with One More Chance (2007), another Filipino film that explores second chances in love and the consequences of choices in a relationship
Like One More Chance, The House of Us portrays raw emotions and the difficult path toward forgiveness and reconciliation

Additionally, it takes inspiration from classic romance tropes found in both literature and film, such as the idea of lovers growing apart due to personal ambitions but later finding a way to reconnect
These references are used effectively to enhance the film’s storytelling, making it feel familiar yet fresh

"The Hows of Us" is a Philippine romantic drama that left me with a combination of emotions – from the euphoria of first love to the heartache of its inevitable problems and the heartwarming process of reunion
The movie explores the intricacies of relationships, emphasizing the fluctuations that come with loving, pursuing ambitions, and developing as a person
What really makes "The Hows of Us" work is its strong Filipino identity
The movie features recognizable social dynamics, family values, and the emphasis on relationships in Filipino culture
The location, a warm and inviting home that George inherited from his late grandmother, is symbolic of the strong sense of family and tradition found in Filipino society
The struggle of the characters with family expectations, financial burdens, and the chase for their dreams is very relatable to most Filipinos
The movie's own Filipino touch can be seen in its characters, dialogue, and storyline
The characters themselves sound and look distinctly Filipino, as their body language, reactions, and dialogue all resonate well with the local population
The fact that the plot dwells so much on family, tradition, and dealing with the demands of society lends the movie a characteristically Filipino tone
"The Hows of Us" is a movie that resonates with Filipino experiences, capturing the spirit of love, family, and self-discovery in a cultural setting that is both familiar and endearing

The Hows of Us (2018) is a Filipino romantic drama film directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina and starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla
The film tells the story of Primo and George, a young couple who dream of a future together but struggle with the realities of love, ambition, and personal growth
Plot SummaryGeorge and Primo are college sweethearts who move in together, hoping to build a life around their shared dreams
However, their relationship is tested as Primo's pursuit of a music career leads to disappointments, while George, who is more practical, begins to question their future
The movie explores how love can be both a source of strength and a challenge when personal ambitions collide with relationships
Review As a student, the film resonates deeply because it highlights themes of ambition, sacrifice, and personal growth—issues many young people face
The story is realistic, showing that love alone is not always enough to sustain a relationship
Kathryn Bernardo delivers a heartfelt performance as George, portraying the struggles of someone torn between love and self-respect
Daniel Padilla, as Primo, effectively shows the frustration of chasing dreams while holding onto a relationship
The cinematography and soundtrack add to the emotional impact, making key scenes more powerful
The script is well-written, with dialogues that capture real-life struggles
One of the most relatable aspects of the film is the message about knowing when to hold on and when to let go—a lesson relevant not only in relationships but also in personal aspirations
Conclusion Overall, “The Hows of Us” is a must-watch, especially for students who are navigating love, career goals, and personal growth
It teaches the importance of communication, compromise, and self-worth
The movie is emotional, thought-provoking, and inspiring, making it a great film for young audiences
‘The Hows of Us’ is a 2018 Filipino romantic drama directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina, starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla

As their relationship faces a lot of challenges along with their career progress, they must decide whether to keep fighting for their love or let go for their own individual happiness

It was easy to connect with the struggles of Primo and George, making their story feel real and authentic
There were moments of kilig (romantic excitement), especially in the early stages of their relationship, but as they grew together conflicts arose, I felt the pain and frustration of their struggles
The film’s emotional depth made it hard not to sympathize with both characters, especially George, who had to make difficult choices for her standing in the relationship and the stake of her future
The ending will leave you with an emotional strain that is bittersweet yet satisfying impact
Their dialogue felt natural and realistic, blending Filipino and English like everyday conversations
Their emotional exchanges, especially during conflicts, made them more authentic and relatable
The movie reflects Filipino culture through family values, sacrifices, and dreams
The setting, character names, and struggles with career and relationships make it deeply relatable to Filipino audiences

The Hows of Us* (2018) is an affecting study in love, sacrifice, and the trials of maturing together—or apart—through time

Directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina and starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla, the film tracks Primo and George, a couple whose erstwhile brilliant future is gradually extinguished by ambition, disillusionment, and the harsh realities of adulthood

What is particularly Filipino about *The Hows of Us* is its visceral emotional center, one that speaks to the very notion of *hugot*—that bare, gut-level pull of emotion oftentimes associated with individual histories of love and heartbreak
Primo's quest for his ambitions, with George lugging the burden of prudence, reflects a common Filipino dynamic in which aspiration and responsibility tend to war against one another

The fact that *pamilya* is an important consideration in their choices also makes the story more rooted in Filipino culture, reaffirming the way that love is seldom just between two individuals, but wrapped up in family obligations
The movie also toys with the concept of *sayang*—that aching, lingering sorrow when love fails because of everything
Although *The Hows of Us* provides closure, it dwells on the heartache of nearly losing someone, so it is understandable to anyone who has ever clung to love a little too long
It does not merely pose the question of whether love is worth fighting for, but whether love by itself is ever sufficient
Would the life of Primo and George have been the same if they were not in the Philippines
Maybe not
The cultural significance of *kapit* (holding on), *tiis* (patience), and the anticipation of *pagtatagal* (enduring love) influence their journey
Deep down, *The Hows of Us* is not simply a love story—it is a testament to what it is to love as a Filipino
The Hows of Us is a beautifully written film that captures the complexities of love, commitment, and personal growth in a long-term relationship

The screenplay is deeply emotional and relatable, presenting a realistic portrayal of how love isn't just about grand romantic gestures but also about patience, sacrifice, and navigating life's uncertainties together

"The Hows of Us" is a poignant exploration of love, sacrifice, and the complexities of sustaining a long-term relationship

Unlike many conventional romance films that often present fairy-tale endings and idealized narratives, this movie authentically examines the tough choices couples must face, especially the delicate balance between pursuing personal dreams and nurturing a commitment to a loved one
The palpable chemistry between Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla enhances the emotional depth of their characters’ journey
The film expertly integrates "hugot" lines—expressions that resonate with real-life experiences of heartbreak and hope—adding a layer of relatability that connects with viewers on a personal level
A defining aspect of this film is its depiction of Filipino values, particularly the emphasis on perseverance, the significance of family, and the necessity of shared responsibilities
These principles are fundamental to Filipino relationships, allowing George and Primo’s struggles to resonate even more profoundly with the audience
Their story intertwines themes of survival and mutual support, grounding their experience in a relatable reality
Moreover, "The Hows of Us" leaves a lasting impression by conveying that love encompasses far more than grand gestures or passionate romances
It illustrates that true love often requires hard work, compromise, and a steadfast commitment to one another—especially during challenging times
The film ultimately serves as a poignant reminder that enduring love is forged not only through moments of joy but also amid shared struggles and unwavering dedication to each other
"The Hows of Us" pinatunayan sa atin na walang patutunguhan ang isang relasyon kung may isa sa inyo ang makasarili

While their relationship may never be perfect, they have matured and learnt to negotiate their differences in a healthier manner, indicating a bright future
The film, demonstrating that love necessitates ongoing effort, understanding, and adaptation—all of which Primo and George are now prepared to accept

The Hows of Us is a deeply emotional and thought-provoking film that explores the complexities of love, dreams, and sacrifice

Directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina and starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla, the film follows the journey of Primo and George—two young lovers whose relationship is tested by ambition, failure, and personal growth
One of the strongest aspects of the film is how Filipino it feels, from its themes of family expectations to the struggle of chasing dreams while maintaining relationships

Primo, an aspiring musician, embodies the passion and persistence of many Filipinos pursuing creative careers, while George represents the pragmatic side—someone who wants stability and security in life
Their struggles resonate with many, especially those who have had to choose between love and personal aspirations
The dialogue also reflects the way many Filipinos speak, blending English and Filipino naturally
There are several hugot moments—lines filled with raw emotion that hit deep—especially during George and Primo’s confrontations
One of the most memorable lines, “Pagod na pagod na ako
” encapsulates the exhaustion of fighting for a love that no longer feels equal
The film also plays with the idea of sayang—a relationship that could have worked if circumstances had been different
While it does not completely follow the tragic romance trope, it still presents a mature take on love: that loving someone isn’t just about passion but also about effort, compromise, and timing
The Hows of Us is a story of love, forgiveness, understanding, and struggle
I had heartbreak, happiness, and butterflies in my stomach while watching the film
Their relationship has the feel of a rollercoaster ride
On certain days, they both feel so happy and loved
The following day, however, their relationship is at its worst, with both of them detesting one another
It is true that challenges are an essential aspect of a relationship in order to strengthen it
But when Primo and George make the decision to part ways, they become so much better
In the film, George always shows concern and prioritizes her family, reflecting Filipino culture
They are always present, even in her dreams
Being in a relationship, their experience helped me understand that love is unpredictable

In the 2018 Filipino love drama The Hows of Us, Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla play the lead roles

It centers on Primo and George, a couple whose relationship is put to the strain by their conflicting goals—Primo's difficulties as a musician and George's need for security—and is directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina
The film highlights the strong chemistry between the leads and features outstanding performances, particularly from Kathryn Bernardo
It is extremely relatable since it examines themes of love, sacrifice, and second chances
It's among the top KathNiel films because of its profound emotional content, excellent directing, and breathtaking photography
After re-watching this movie (the hows of us), I resonated in so many ways
This movie is a reflection on personal growth, the need for compromise, and sometimes painful process of maturing within a relationship

The portrayal of George and Primo’s love has not been grand

There’s nothing to be proud of that George is devoted to a person who kept proving to her and to other people that he’s just a no good
It’s hard that they’ve reached the ultimate slump in their relationship and they have to realize that it’s no longer healthy to stay in that relationship
Most definitely, it is silly and true for us humans, that we only find ourselves and make time to right our wrongs when we’ve lost the most important thing in our lives
